subsection.title: A Tool for Solving Exponential Equations
subsection.p: Logarithms are functions that, among other things, can be used to solve exponential equations. If we have an exponential equation in which the variable is in the exponent, we use logarithms to isolate the variable.
By definition, a logarithm is an exponent.

assemblage.p: In the exponential equation b^{y}=x The exponent y is the logarithm so y=log_{b}(x)

subsection.p: There are at least three useful rules about logarithms:

li.p: This first rule is often used to bring the exponent down after applying the logarithm, the exponent becomes a factor.
The next two rules are sometimes used to combine two terms involving logarithms, or to split one term into two.

subsection.p: The first rule is definitely the most useful. I used to have a pocket knife with 10 different tools folded into it, but I only used one. Rule 1 is that tool. It allows us to take an exponential expression and bring down the exponent so we can isolate it.
If we end up with an equation that looks like (0.337)^{\text{?}}=1.272 as in, I wonder what the exponent is?, we can use a logarithmic function to find the answer.
Although most likely a variable is used instead of a question mark like (0.337)^{x}=1.272 where x is the unknown value we are trying to find.
Using rule \# 1 and applying any logarithm to both sides of the equation we can work our way towards isolating the unknown variable x.

example.title: Use rule \# 1 to isolate and solve for the unknown variable

statement.p: In this case we used \log, but we get the same answer using the natural logarithm, \ln, instead. Try it!

It does not matter what base logarithm you use, as long as you use the same \log_{b} on both sides of the equation. However, it does help to use a function that is readily available on most calculators like base 10 (\log), or base e (\ln).

subsection.p: Now you try it. Solve an exponential equation using rule \# 1.

introduction.p: How many 7 \% increases is the same as one 49 \% increase?

statement.p: The growth factor associated with a 7 \% increase is b=
The equation below literally states, An unknown number of growth factors b=1.07 is the same as 1.49
Apply your favorite logarithm to each side of the equation. My favorite is \ln, so the equation is now \ln(1.07)^{x}= \ln(1.49)
Invoke rule \# 1 so that the exponent can come down in front of the expression on the left x \ln(1.07)= \ln(1.49)
Last step, isolate the variable by dividing both sides by \ln(1.07), and what do you get?

subsection.p: Rule \# 1 is great, but if we want to use it as the main tool we have to know when it applies and how to deal with the situation if the rule does not apply.

statement.p: At first glance it seems you can apply rule \# 1, but is that right? Rule \# 1 states \log_{b}(N^{x})=x \log_{b}(N)

Notice how rule \# 1 assumes you have one side written as N^{x} with nothing else in front (no coefficient)? The left side of our equation has a coefficient of 3 in front of the exponential3(2.83)^{x} The constant 3 is keeping us from using rule \# 1. That constant either has to be moved or we have to use another rule (if there is one that applies).
We can fix the situation by rearranging the equation to match the format of rule \# 1 or we could use rule \# 2 because at least it matches the format of our equation.

solution.p: The constant 3 needs to be moved so only the exponential remains on the left side of the equation. (2.83)^{x}=\frac{15}{3} Voilà! Now we have the correct form to use rule \# 1. Apply your favorite logarithm to both sides. I'll use \ln this time because I used \log in the last example. \ln (2.83)^{x}= \ln \big( \frac{15}{3} \big) The exponent comes down and we have: x \ln(2.83)= \ln \big( \frac{15}{3} \big)The last step is to isolate the variable x= \frac{\ln \big( \frac{15}{3} \big)}{\ln(2.83)} so that (rounded to three decimals): x \approx 1.547
In English the second rule says, The log of a product is equal to the sum of the logs.

Applying \ln to both sides of our equation, we in fact have the log of the product 3 times (2.83)^{x} on the left side \ln (3(2.83)^{x})=\ln(15) Use rule \# 2 to write the left side of the equation as the sum of the logs \ln(3)+\ln(2.83)^{x}=\ln(15) Remember the goal is to isolate the variable x which we can now do since, on the left side, one term has x and the other does not.

Subtracting \ln(3) from both sides we get \ln (2.83)^{x}=\ln(15)-\ln(3) Look, we get to use rule \# 1 anyway! On the left we bring down the exponent, x x \ln(2.83)=\ln(15)-\ln(3) Now isolate x x=\frac{\ln(15)-\ln(3)}{\ln(2.83)} We get the same answer as before x \approx 1.547
Which method did you like better?

introduction.p: Of course we could have just solved the equation 3(2.83)^{x}=15 graphically and avoided the algebra all together.

The graph of the exponential function f(x)=3(2.83)^{x} will reach different heights depending on the input x. What x value makes the graph y=15 units high?
Drag the output value to y=15 to find the solution rounded to 2 decimal places.

conclusion.p: A note about solving. In the two algebra examples we were able to find exact solutions x= \frac{\ln \big( \frac{15}{3} \big)}{\ln(2.83)} is exact.

We then entered the exact expressions into a calculator and found approximations rounded to three decimal places. Though graphically may seem quick and easy, most often we can only get an approximation to the answer.

subsection.p: Finally, we could just ask a computer to solve the equation for us. Many websites have tools for solving equations such as: 3(2.83)\text{^x = 15} You may wish to perform a web search for such a website.
Technology can now do much of what only people could do in the past. The question is no longer Can you solve an equation?, the question is Do you have the right equation?
Computers can solve all kinds of equations, but so far only people have the ability to set the problems up.

subsection.title: Domain and Range
subsection.p: Because a logarithm is just another kind of function, it has a domain and a range and the graph of a logarithmic function has its own characteristics that make it unique.
We can use our language approach to understand the domain and range of a logarithmic function. Remember the literal translation of the expression log(x) is The power of 10 that gives you x.

li.p: log(100) means The power of 10 that gives you 100.
So log(100)=2 which says, The power of 10 that gives you 100 is 2. Since 10^{2}=100
log_{3}(81) means, The power of 3 that gives you 81.
So log_{3}(81)=4 which says, The power of 3 that gives you 81 is 4. Since 3^{4}=81

subsection.p: Recall the domain of a function f is the set of all possible inputs the function can use (values that make sense for the function).
Let f(x)=log_{3}(x) where x is the input.
Consider negative input values, like x=-9 and think about the meaning of log_{3}(-9)
The statement makes no sense. You cannot get a negative result if all you have is positive 3's multiplied together. At least one has to be negative!
Since any negative input leads us to the same conclusion, it turns out logarithms cannot accept negative inputs.
For a similar reason logarithmic functions cannot have zero as an input. If you ask How many factors of 3 does it take to get 0? or just 3^{?}=0, it should be clear there is no answer.
Therefore, the domain of any logarithmic function is all inputs that are greater than or equal to zero.

For the range we must consider all the possible outputs we should expect from the function. In the case of the logarithm, an output is the exponent value needed to get a particular input \log_{b}(\text{input})=\text{output}

statement.p: Consider y=log_{3}(x)
For any input x how many 3's does it take to get that x value? The answer (output) is the y value.
For inputs 0 \lt x \lt 1 the results are negative, so y \lt 0.
For inputs x \gt 1 the results are always positive, so y \gt 0
If the input is x=1 the result is zero (log_{3}(1)=0 because, What power of 3 gives you 1? The 0 power.
After a few tries we should begin to realize the range of log_{3}(x) is all real numbers.

subsection.p: It turns out the range for any base of a log function like log_{b}(x) is all real numbers.

subsection.p: The vertical asymptotevertical asymptote is like a vertical boundary that the function cannot cross. In the case of the logarithm y=log_{b}(x) the asymptote is the y-axis with equation x=0 and the function only exists to the right of this boundary.
This supports our assertion that the domain of y=log_{b}(x) is all x \gt 0 (to the right of the y-axis).

subsection.title: Change of Base
subsection.p: So far, when evaluating expressions like \log_{3}(9) it seems we need to know the answer before we evaluate. How do you evaluate an expression when you don't already know the answer?

statement.p: Evaluate \log_{3}(0.1822)
Solution:
We know the answer should be negative because we are trying to get 0.1822 which is less than 1

Your calculator may already have a log of any base option. Today, in the 21st century we can also find the answer, for free, on the web. For instance, go to Desmos.com. Type \log{underscore key}(0.1822) into one of the cells. You should see the answer as \log_{3}(0.1822) \approx -1.5498 and you can get more decimal places if you want.

But before the web, it used to be that calculators only had one or two options for logarithms, (and before calculators there were things called "slide rules" and books with pages and pages of tables of logarithms).

Here is an old school method of evaluating a logarithm expression. The method is called change of base which means you change the base from whatever it is to either base 10, \log, or base e, \ln, because most calculators have those built in.

Set up an equation in which y is the answer you want. Use the definition of the logarithm to turn the log equation into an exponential equation. Then solve the exponential equation using any base log you want. In this example we use base 10, \log.

statement.p: Solutions:
What is the percent hourly decay rate?
The opening sentence is telling us we must use an exponential model because the decay is a constant percent. The sentence goes on to tell us what kind of decay model and the percent rate of decay.
The word continuous is telling us to use base e. Therefore we can write the formula for decay as Ae^{-kt} where k is the continuous decay constant k=

The first question is about the hourly percent decay. We were given the continuous hourly decay. These are two different things.

A discrete model would look like Ab^{t} where b is the hourly growth factor we are trying to find. But both the discrete and continuous models have to predict the same behavior. Therefore the two formulas have to be equal they have to produce the same values. A(b)^{t}=A(e^{-k})^t Notice how the parentheses are used to show that both sides are actually the same thing. Both say A(something)^{t}. The somethings must be the same number. That is: b = e^{-k}

The half-life is the time is takes to reduce the substance to half its value. We do not know how much substance there is, but we do know there is something.
Earlier we called the initial amount A. In some time we will have \frac{1}{2}A. How much time? The answer is the half-life.

exercise.title: Population Growth and Time to Triple

statement.p: A population increases at an annual rate of about \%.

li.p: What is the continuous annual growth rate?

statement.p: Solutions:
What is the continuous annual growth rate?
The opening sentence is telling us we must use an exponential model because the growth is a constant percent. The sentence goes on to tell us what kind of growth model and the percent rate of growth.

Annual percent growth is called discrete growth. Not because it is annual, per se, but because it is measured at the end of some finite time interval. Other examples of discrete growth (or decay) would be described as monthly or daily etc. Another way to tell it is discrete is the absence of the word continuous. If the growth is not continuous, then it is discrete.
A discrete model looks like Ab^{t} where in our case b is the annual growth factor and A represents the initial size of the population which we are not given.
A continuous model would be Ae^{kt} where k is the continuous growth constant and A still represents the initial amount.
These models must be equal because they are describing the same population. Therefore A(b)^{t}=A(e^{k})^{t} Notice what is the same on each side and what is different.
In order to be equal b=e^{k}.
Solving the equation for k
The continuous growth constant in our problem is k \approx (round your answer to 2 decimal places)
This represents a continuous percent growth rate of about Include units and round to 2 decimal places)

statement.p: Remember, you can always solve graphically too!
In the study of populations (population dynamics) the situation often arises where we must solve logarithmic equations.

For instance, when searching for an equation to model a population that has a carrying capacity (a maximum number the population can sustain) we can end up with an equation like \ln(P)-\ln(1-P)=tin which the goal is to isolate P as a function of t. It is a good exercise in algebra and log rules.
Use rule \# 3 to write the left side of the equation \ln(P)-\ln(1-P)=t as one term.
Use the definition of the logarithm that states \log_{b}(x)=y means b^{y}=x, to rewrite the equation \ln(\frac{P}{1-P})=t as an exponential equation \frac{P}{1-P}=e^{t}
Multiply both sides of the equation \frac{P}{1-P}=e^{t} by (1-P) and distribute on the right side to get P=e^{t}-Pe^{t}
Collect the terms with P on the left of P+Pe^{t}=e^{t} and factor out P so that P(1+e^{t})=e^{t}
Now solve for P to get the final answer
This kind of equation is called logistical and you will study it more in-depth if you continue your studies through calculus.
